#Text=Work Out the Payback Period
#Text=The " payback period " is an accounting metric used for investment decision making .

column3:
abstract[4]	new[4]	_	_
2-3	34-41	payback	abstract|abstract[4]	giv|new[4]	coref	4-6
2-4	42-48	period	abstract[4]	new[4]	_	_
2-5	49-50

column1: #Text=The metric is very simple , and is designed to estimate how quickly a company will recover a cash investment .
#Text=When used alone , the payback period can be misleading and oversimplified .
#Text=However , when analyzed alongside other decision-making metrics , the payback period can be clarifying and helpful .
#Text=Learning how to work out the payback period for a particular investment or project is a matter of estimating a few cash flows and performing a simple calculation .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Familiarize yourself with the basic computation of the payback period .
#Text=The payback period specifies how quickly ( in years ) the cash invested in a particular project will be recovered .
#Text=For example , consider a project that requires a $ 100,000 cash outflow immediately , but is expected to bring in an additional $ 10,000 in cash each year for 20 years .
#Text=The payback period is 10 years , because after 10 years the original cash outflow has been recovered ( $ 10,000 * 10 = $ 100,000 ) .
#Text=Note that the payback period calculation does not take the time value of money into account .
#Text=Future cash flows are not discounted to their present values , but are instead used at face value .
#Text=Note also that the payback period only considers cash flows , and does not take into account the effect of depreciation or other non-cash expenses .
#Text=This , along with the time value exclusion , is a shortcoming of the payback calculation .
#Text=Assess the immediate cash outflow associated with the project in question .
#Text=This is the amount that must be paid out in cash at the start of a project .
#Text=For example , consider a company 's decision to buy a new copy machine to replace an old one .
#Text=The machine costs $ 10,000 , and is expected to save $ 1000 in toner and electricity each year for 8 years , and then save $ 800 each year for the next 10 years .
#Text=The immediate cash outflow associated with this project is $ 10,000 .
#Text=Assess the future cash flows expected from a project .
#Text=These cash flows should be estimated before undertaking any project .
#Text=Before calculating the payback period , it helps to write these cash flows down on paper in timeline form .
#Text=In the example above , there are 8 cash flows of $ 1000 , followed by 10 cash flows of $ 800 .
#Text=Sum together the future cash flows until you recover the initial cash investment .
#Text=Begin adding the cash flows together in chronological order .
#Text=When the sum is equal to the initial outflow , you have found the payback period .
#Text=In the example above , after 1 year the company has recovered $ 1000 .
#Text=After 5 years , the company has recovered $ 5000 .
#Text=After 8 years , $ 8000 has been recovered .
#Text=After 10 years , $ 9600 has been recovered .
#Text=After 11 years , $ 10,400 has been recovered ; this amount exceeds the initial investment , so the payback period must be between 10 and 11 years .
#Text=The cash flow in year 11 was $ 800 .
#Text=After $ 400 of this cash was received , the initial investment of $ 10,000 had been recovered .
#Text=This is exactly half of that year 's cash flow , so the payback period for this investment is 10.5 years .
#Text=Video
#Text=Tips
#Text=The sample calculations above will also work when expressed in other currencies .
#Text=The payback period should always be used in conjunction with other decision-making metrics , such as return on investment ( ROI ) and internal rate of return ( IRR ) .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Pencil
#Text=Paper
